tips.tip: Abscessus requires IV antibiotics as first-line treatment. Standard intensive phase is 8-12 weeks of IV meds (typically Amikacin + Imipenem or Tigecycline) followed by 12-18 months of oral continuation therapy. This is NON-negotiable for abscessus - oral-only treatment is insufficient for this highly resistant species.
tips.notes: Abscessus subspecies abscessus erm41 is most drug-resistant. Treatment duration often 14+ months total.

tips.tip: Insist on baseline hearing test BEFORE starting IV Amikacin, then monthly audiograms during treatment. Hearing loss from Amikacin is PERMANENT and can progress to deafness even after stopping the drug. Some patients have lost hearing completely in one ear or 70% in both ears.
tips.notes: One patient became deaf in right ear with 70% loss in left from IV Amikacin. Another had PICC pulled after 6 weeks due to hearing loss.

tips.tip: PICC lines allow normal arm mobility and most activities - you can do line dancing, hiking, biking, aerobics, and weight lifting with a protective sleeve covering the insertion site. Only restriction: NO water activities (swimming, hot tubs, scuba diving) while PICC line is in place.
tips.notes: Use nude-colored nylon sock with toe cut off as inexpensive sleeve alternative to white mesh sleeve. Plastic shower sleeve from Amazon allows quick showers.

tips.tip: Fresh IV with each infusion (MWF schedule) is an option if you cannot tolerate PICC line due to hypermobile Ehlers-Danlos or other vein issues. Discuss intramuscular injection backup plan if you blow too many veins during infusions.
tips.notes: Patient with Ehlers-Danlos refused PICC to continue weight lifting/rowing - doctor agreed to fresh IV approach with IM injections as backup.

tips.tip: Flush PICC line with heparin on non-infusion days. On infusion days (typically 3x/week at clinic), nurses handle the flushing. Proper hand washing before and after each flush is critical to prevent line infections.
tips.notes: Entire IV infusion takes ~20 minutes for medication delivery. Some patients feel dizzy/unbalanced afterward - sit for 15 minutes before getting up.

tips.tip: Home IV administration is feasible even in rural areas without infusion centers. Nursing staff will coach you and your spouse/caregiver to administer IV Amikacin safely at home. Ask assertive questions, request written instructions, and get a reliable phone number for the nurse.
tips.notes: Amikacin comes in easy-to-use ball form. Entire procedure takes 20 minutes.

tips.tip: Slowing IV Amikacin infusion from 30 minutes to 1 hour can eliminate tingling/paresthesia in hands and feet. Report any pins-and-needles sensations to your infusion nurse immediately - this is a dose rate issue, not necessarily a reason to stop treatment.
tips.notes: Patient had tingling in wrists/fingers at beginning of treatment - extending infusion time solved it completely.

tips.tip: Inhaled Amikacin (plain generic via nebulizer, not Arikayce) is equally effective as liposomal Arikayce but costs $7/month copay vs. $$$$ for Arikayce. Mix plain Amikacin solution with 3% normal saline in nebulizer cup 3x/week. This avoids Arikayce's 'inert' ingredients that cause side effects in sensitive patients.
tips.notes: Patient dubbed 'side effect queen' failed on Arikayce but had NO side effects on plain inhaled Amikacin. MAC-free since 2022 using this approach + Azithromycin + Bedaquiline.

tips.tip: Watch-and-wait for abscessus IS valid if you're asymptomatic and colony count is low. Some patients with nodular bronchiectasis clear abscessus naturally with aggressive airway clearance (7% saline 2x daily + ACT + exercise) and never need IV treatment. Get expert evaluation at NJH before committing to brutal IV regimen.
tips.notes: One patient cleared abscessus in 3 weeks with ACT alone, NJH determined she was clearing it naturally. However, recurrence/reinfection rate is 50% for abscessus.

tips.tip: Abscessus treatment is DOABLE and life can be good during/after treatment. Many patients tolerate 14-18 months of treatment well, with negative cultures achieved. One 91-year-old post-treatment patient has breathing tests 'off the chart' good and remains MAC-free since 2006 lingulectomy.
tips.notes: Patient on week 58 at home is swimming 3km 5x/week, traveled to UK/Europe from New Zealand, dreadful cough gone. Another patient 2 months in already feels more energy, not coughing.

tips.tip: Oral medications (Clofazimine, Omadacycline/Nuzyra, Doxycycline, Linezolid) cause most of the nausea in abscessus treatment, not inhaled Amikacin. If nausea becomes unbearable, your doctor may pause oral meds temporarily while continuing inhaled Amikacin to maintain progress.
tips.notes: Multiple patients confirmed Nuzyra causes severe nausea. Weight loss is major concern - consultant may prioritize stabilizing weight over continuing full regimen.

tips.tip: Take anti-nausea medication (Zofran, Ondansetron) 1 hour BEFORE taking Nuzyra (Omadacycline). This prevents nausea rather than treating it after onset. If nausea persists, try taking Nuzyra with crackers or food (less effective but tolerable), staying upright/elevated after dosing, and adjusting timing.
tips.notes: Nuzyra called 'gold bars' due to extreme cost. One patient conquered nausea with Zofran pretreatment and completed full course.

tips.tip: Ginger chews (Gin-Gins by The Ginger People in green package from Amazon) help tremendously with IV treatment nausea. Nurses at NJH recommend these specifically for getting through intensive treatment phases.
tips.notes: 91-year-old patient who had lingulectomy in 2006 credits ginger chews with managing nausea during treatment.

tips.tip: For antibiotic-associated diarrhea from IV regimens: Use Banatrol + Florastor probiotics, rotate multiple probiotic strains (Culturelle, etc), drink kefir (TJ's strawberry recommended), take probiotics mid-day away from antibiotics. If severe, try psyllium husk mixed with jam/applesauce.
tips.notes: Patient on Azithromycin 500mg + Linezolid 600mg + Tigecycline 50mg IV found rotating probiotics + kefir essential for gut health during year-long treatment.

tips.tip: Extrapulmonary NTM (skin/soft tissue infections, joint infections) requires different IV approach than pulmonary disease. M. chelonae in skin/soft tissue needs immediate imaging and aggressive treatment, especially if immunosuppressed. Joint infections may need multiple debridement surgeries alongside IV antibiotics.
tips.notes: Patient with shoulder MAC needed 4 debridement surgeries + IV antibiotics. High-risk scenario with immunosuppression (RA, long-term steroids).

tips.tip: IV Amikacin fatigue is REAL and significant. Many patients report extreme tiredness during/after infusions, making driving difficult and requiring afternoon naps. Schedule infusions when you can rest afterward - working full-time while on IV Amikacin is very challenging.
tips.notes: One patient too dizzy to golf or drive after Amikacin. Another found tiredness/fatigue didn't improve over 1+ year of treatment - persists until treatment stops.

tips.tip: If abscessus returns after successful eradication, you may delay repeat treatment if you're asymptomatic and symptoms aren't severe. One patient waited 6 years before repeating brutal 14-month IV regimen, reluctant due to permanent hearing loss from first round.
tips.notes: Patient with abscessus susp abscessus erm41 successfully treated 8 years ago, now reinfected but waiting to treat again due to previous hearing loss and harsh side effects.

tips.tip: For M. chimaera (associated with heater-cooler devices during cardiac surgery), if 8 months of nebulized Arikayce doesn't impact infection significantly, escalate to 8 weeks of daily IV infusions. Chimaera can require more aggressive IV approach than standard MAC.
tips.notes: Patient's ID specialist decided IV treatment indicated after inadequate response to Arikayce for M. chimaera.

key_insights: Abscessus is non-negotiable IV territory: Unlike MAC which can sometimes be watched or treated with oral-only regimens, abscessus subspecies (especially erm41) requires initial IV intensive phase. This is the #1 use case for IV antibiotics in NTM - watch-and-wait only applies to truly asymptomatic low-colony-count cases under expert supervision.

Hearing loss prevention is critical-level monitoring: IV Amikacin ototoxicity is PERMANENT and can progress to complete deafness. Baseline + monthly audiograms are non-negotiable. Some patients lost 70-100% hearing in one or both ears. This makes IV Amikacin high-stakes compared to inhaled formulations.

PICC lines are less limiting than feared: Patients successfully do line dancing, weight lifting, hiking, biking, aerobics with PICC in place using protective sleeve. Main restriction is water activities. Fresh IV 3x/week is alternative for those who can't tolerate PICC (Ehlers-Danlos, difficult veins).

Plain inhaled Amikacin beats expensive Arikayce for sensitive patients: Generic Amikacin mixed with 3% saline in nebulizer costs $7/month vs $$$ for Arikayce, avoids Arikayce's 'inert' ingredients causing side effects, and is equally effective. Self-described 'side effect queen' had zero issues with plain version after Arikayce made her 'deathly ill.'

Nausea is mostly from ORAL meds, not IV/inhaled Amikacin: Clofazimine, Nuzyra (Omadacycline), Linezolid cause the brutal nausea. Doctors may pause oral meds temporarily to stabilize weight while continuing inhaled Amikacin. Proactive Zofran 1 hour before Nuzyra is game-changer.

Abscessus treatment is a marathon but doable: 14-18 months total (initial IV phase + long oral continuation). Patients successfully travel internationally, swim 3km 5x/week, work during treatment. One 91-year-old remains MAC-free since 2006 with 'off the chart' breathing tests.

Home IV administration works even in rural areas: No infusion center nearby? Nurses coach patients/spouses to administer IV Amikacin at home. Ball-form Amikacin makes this feasible. Critical to get written instructions and reliable nurse phone number.

Infusion rate adjustment solves paresthesia: Tingling/pins-and-needles in hands/feet during IV Amikacin is dose rate issue, not drug intolerance. Slowing infusion from 30 min to 1 hour eliminates tingling completely - don't quit treatment over this.

Extrapulmonary NTM is different beast: Joint infections (MAC in shoulder) need multiple debridement surgeries + IV antibiotics. Skin/soft tissue NTM (chelonae) high-risk with immunosuppression. Don't assume pulmonary NTM protocols apply - needs specialist imaging and aggressive approach.

Fatigue from IV Amikacin persists throughout treatment: Extreme tiredness making driving difficult, requiring afternoon naps, incompatible with full-time work for many patients. This doesn't improve with adaptation over months - it's physiological response that resolves when treatment stops.

common_questions.question: Do I really need IV antibiotics for abscessus or can I just do oral meds?
common_questions.answer: Abscessus requires IV intensive phase (8-12 weeks minimum) followed by oral continuation. Oral-only treatment is insufficient for this highly resistant species. Only exception: truly asymptomatic low-colony-count cases under expert care (like NJH) where watch-and-wait with aggressive airway clearance may clear infection naturally.

common_questions.question: Will I go deaf from IV Amikacin?
common_questions.answer: Hearing loss is significant risk but not universal. INSIST on baseline audiogram before starting and monthly hearing tests during treatment. Some patients have zero hearing issues, others lose 70-100% hearing permanently. Early detection allows stopping Amikacin before complete deafness.

common_questions.question: Can I still exercise with a PICC line in my arm?
common_questions.answer: Yes! Patients do line dancing, weight lifting, hiking, biking, rowing with PICC line + protective sleeve. Only restriction: NO water activities (swimming, hot tubs). If you absolutely need to lift heavy or have hypermobile joints, discuss fresh IV 3x/week or intramuscular injections as alternatives.

common_questions.question: How do I shower with a PICC line?
common_questions.answer: Use plastic shower sleeve from Amazon to keep PICC insertion site dry. Take quick showers. No baths, swimming, or soaking. On non-infusion days, you must flush PICC line with heparin - nurses show you how.

common_questions.question: Should I use expensive Arikayce or plain generic Amikacin for inhaling?
common_questions.answer: If you're sensitive to medications, try plain generic Amikacin mixed with 3% saline in nebulizer FIRST before spending $$$ on Arikayce. Costs ~$7/month copay, equally effective, and avoids Arikayce's extra ingredients. Some patients tolerate plain version perfectly after Arikayce made them deathly ill.

common_questions.question: Why am I SO nauseous on abscessus treatment - is it the IV Amikacin?
common_questions.answer: Nausea is mostly from ORAL medications (Clofazimine, Nuzyra/Omadacycline, Linezolid), NOT from inhaled/IV Amikacin. Take Zofran 1 hour BEFORE your worst offender (usually Nuzyra). Try Nuzyra with crackers, stay upright after dosing. Ginger chews (Gin-Gins brand) help. Your doctor may pause oral meds temporarily while continuing inhaled Amikacin to stabilize weight.

common_questions.question: Can I administer IV Amikacin at home if there's no infusion center near me?
common_questions.answer: Yes! Many patients in rural areas successfully do home IV administration. Nurses will coach you and your spouse/caregiver thoroughly. Amikacin comes in ball form that's easier to use than traditional IV bags. Get written instructions and reliable nurse phone number before starting.

common_questions.question: My hands and feet tingle during IV Amikacin infusions - do I need to stop?
common_questions.answer: NO! This is infusion rate issue, not drug intolerance. Ask nurse to slow infusion from 30 minutes to 1 hour. Tingling should disappear completely. Don't quit treatment over this - it's easily fixable.

common_questions.question: How tired will I be on IV Amikacin?
common_questions.answer: Fatigue is significant and real. Many patients can't drive safely after infusions, need afternoon naps, find full-time work very difficult. This doesn't improve over months - it's physiological response lasting throughout treatment. Plan work accommodations or medical leave if needed.

common_questions.question: How long do I need IV antibiotics for abscessus?
common_questions.answer: Typical intensive phase: 8-12 weeks IV (some patients 14+ weeks), then 12-18 months oral continuation therapy. Total treatment often 14-18 months. If you cannot tolerate full intensive phase (hearing loss, severe side effects), work with expert to adjust - some patients successfully treated with shorter IV phase.

common_questions.question: What if my abscessus comes back after I was successfully treated?
common_questions.answer: Recurrence/reinfection rate is ~50%. If you're asymptomatic or mildly symptomatic, you can delay retreatment - one patient waited 6 years before repeating brutal regimen. Balance quality of life with risk of progression. Key factors: previous treatment side effects (hearing loss), current symptoms, colony count.

common_questions.question: Why is diarrhea so bad on IV antibiotics and what helps?
common_questions.answer: Antibiotic-associated diarrhea from heavy IV regimens is common. Use Banatrol + Florastor probiotics, rotate multiple strains, drink kefir. Take probiotics mid-day AWAY from antibiotics (not same time). Psyllium husk works for severe cases. Stay hydrated.
